awd_titl_txt: Control of Reconfigurable Battery Energy Storage Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Rechargeable battery systems represent a key enabler for several technologies such as electrified transportation, smart grid, renewables, and green buildings. These systems are increasingly recognized as a driver for moving the world forward into a sustainable energy era. Despite their ever-growing presence, the performance and safety of these systems are fundamentally constrained by how the battery cells are connected inside. Typically, these cells are hardwired. As a result, there is no flexibility to overcome battery failures caused by defects in individual cells, whether created during manufacturing or through malfunction of a cell. This has led to greater interest in reconfigurable battery systems, which use rapid reconfigurable connections between cells to overcome these problems. While there is rapid growth of power electronics architecture and circuit design, the management algorithms to control these devices are not improving at the same pace. This project aims to develop a new control paradigm, through which the system's input control and connection topology adjustment are achieved concurrently. This research, if successful, will significantly improve the reconfigurable battery systems and accelerate their use across diverse sectors. The research-integrated education program will engage K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students through curriculum enhancement, community outreach, and research mentorship. The PI's collaboration with the industry through this project will lead to practical algorithms and tools. As battery systems are central to key devices and equipment used in all sectors this research will not only promote the progress of science in battery technology but help improve technologies used in national health, prosperity, and national defense. 

The scientific focus of this project is to develop a foundational mathematical framework for enabling simultaneous control and topology reconfiguration for reconfigurable battery systems from a network perspective and build a set of control algorithms that take the best advantage of reconfigurability. This research specifically includes: 1) creation of an algebraic graph-theoretic modeling methodology for reconfigurable battery systems, 2) synthesis of a predictive control framework that can optimize control input and reconfigure system-wide connections, and 3) application of the framework to key battery management tasks including optimal charging/discharging, thermal management and cell balancing. The models and algorithms will be subjected to principled evaluation through rigorous theoretical analysis, simulations and experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Battery energy storage is to the 21st century as fossil fuels are to the 20th century. They are just more clean, efficient, and sustainable. Lithium-ion batteries have proven to be one of the most best battery energy storage technologies ever, due to their high energy/power density and long cycle life. The past decade has witnessed their penetration into many sectors, from transportation to grid and from buildings to space systems. While lithium-ion battery systems will be a pillar technology to move the world into a new era of electrification, their performance and safety are fundamentally constrained by hardwiring between battery cells. With the fixed connection, a battery system, which is subject to cell-to-cell manufacturing variations and potential cell faults in operation, can neither adjust individual cells' dynamics toward balanced use nor bypass the faulty cell on the detection of a fault. Thus, this project sought to enable rapid reconfigurable connection between cells to overcome these problems.

The project set an aim on the design, control, and management of reconfigurable lithium-ion battery systems. The research work throughout the period of performance has led to a few outcomes. A summary of the main outcomes is as below.  

First, we propose a novel modular, reconfigurable battery energy storage system architecture. The architecture is characterized by a tight integration of reconfigurable power electronic switches and DC/DC converters. This characteristic enables isolation of faulty cells from the system and allows fine power control for individual cells toward optimal system-level performance. The architecture provides many benefits, including high safety, fault tolerance, cell balancing, and robust power supply.

Second, we developed a catalog of optimal power control and charging control methods for battery systems to improve their operating performance. These methods pursue both optimal cell-to-system-level performance and computational efficiency to facilitate practical battery management applications.

Third, the project launched some studies to construct accurate and computationally fast mathematical models for batteries, due to the central importance of battery modeling for battery management tasks. The studies spawned several novel battery models through a synthesis of ideas from electrochemical modeling, equivalent circuit modeling, and machine learning.

Finally, we explored different battery management problems, including state-of-charge estimation and battery model identification, and developed corresponding solutions. Driven by the prominent role of control in battery management, we proposed a few novel methods for distributed control, nonlinear model predictive control, and particle filtering.

The project produced a series of research articles published in journals and conferences, as well as a pending patent application. Further, the project supported a diversity of educational and outreach activities. Among them, a few Ph.D., master?s, and undergraduate students participated in different research tasks to solve meaningful problems and gain both new knowledge and research skills. Part of the research results were included in the PI?s courses, such as Optimal Estimation, Model Predictive Control, and Energy Storage Systems & Control. Research-related outreach activities were provided to local students to inspire their interest in STEM through some established programs at the University of Kansas and collaboration with a local juvenile detention center.
